articles.headline: Medical Problems Could Include Identity Theft
articles.snippet: Increased use of electronic medical records surely means a rise in ID theft, and many don’t know yet that they are victims.
articles.abstract: Increased use of electronic medical records surely means a rise in ID theft, and many don’t know yet that they are victims.
articles.lead_paragraph: Brandon Sharp, a 37-year-old manager at an oil and gas company in Houston, has never had any real health problems and, luckily, he has never stepped foot in an emergency room. So imagine his surprise a few years ago when he learned he owed thousands of dollars worth of emergency-service medical bills.

articles.headline: Seeking Growth Market, Chip Maker Eyes Solar Cells
articles.snippet: If Taiwan Semiconductor, one of the world’s most formidable manufacturers, moves into solar cells and LED lights, prices could fall sharply.
articles.abstract: If Taiwan Semiconductor, one of the world’s most formidable manufacturers, moves into solar cells and LED lights, prices could fall sharply.
articles.lead_paragraph: HSINCHU, Taiwan  Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, or TSMC, has seen the light and now wants to make some.

articles.headline: Geithner’s Plan on Pay Falls Short
articles.snippet: Stronger regulation of executive compensation at all banks is vital to restrain the risk-taking that has cost taxpayers billions of dollars.
articles.abstract: Stronger regulation of executive compensation at all banks is vital to restrain the risk-taking that has cost taxpayers billions of dollars.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was another one of those Timothy Geithner moments.

articles.headline: Disease of Rich Extends Its Pain to Middle Class
articles.snippet: The rising tide of gout is leading the pharmaceutical industry to rediscover what seemed a disease of the past.
articles.abstract: The rising tide of gout is leading the pharmaceutical industry to rediscover what seemed a disease of the past.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lonnie Matthews, a retired building maintenance engineer in Burlington, N.C., has something in common with King Henry VIII, Sir Isaac Newton and Benjamin Franklin. He has gout.

articles.headline: In Mexican City, Drug War Ills Slip Into Shadows
articles.snippet: A relative calm has enveloped Nuevo Laredo, once ground zero in Mexico’s drug violence.
articles.abstract: A relative calm has enveloped Nuevo Laredo, once ground zero in Mexico’s drug violence.
articles.lead_paragraph: NUEVO LAREDO, Mexico  The reminders of Nuevo Laredo’s violent days still mar its streets  bullet holes and the impacts of grenades where drug traffickers once flaunted their power, boarded-up buildings of merchants who fled the lawlessness, and until they were leveled by the government a few weeks ago, garish roadside shrines to Santa Muerte, the saint of death.

articles.headline: Privacy May Be a Victim in Cyberdefense Plan
articles.snippet: A plan to create a new Pentagon cybercommand is raising privacy and diplomatic concerns.
articles.abstract: A plan to create a new Pentagon cybercommand is raising privacy and diplomatic concerns.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  A plan to create a new Pentagon cybercommand is raising significant privacy and diplomatic concerns, as the Obama administration moves ahead on efforts to protect the nation from cyberattack and to prepare for possible offensive operations against adversaries’ computer networks.
articles.byline: By Thom Shanker and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: F.D.I.C. Is Watching as a Bank Sets Rates
articles.snippet: Government regulators essentially told Ally, an online arm of GMAC, it is paying too much in interest, though depositors can get still higher rates elsewhere.
articles.abstract: Government regulators essentially told Ally, an online arm of GMAC, it is paying too much in interest, though depositors can get still higher rates elsewhere.
articles.lead_paragraph: This is the story of how the federal government essentially told a bank that it was paying too much money in interest to its customers and ordered it to lower the rates. It’s also about why that may not be such a bad thing, if only its logic applied equally to all banks.

articles.headline: Lender’s Role for Fed Makes Some Uneasy
articles.snippet: The central bank has had to decide which of many industries should be eligible for government financing.
articles.abstract: The central bank has had to decide which of many industries should be eligible for government financing.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  For most of its history, the Federal Reserve has been a high temple of monetary matters, guiding the economy by setting interest rates but remaining aloof from the messy details of day-to-day business.

articles.headline: Industry Slumps, but Prius Inspires Waiting List
articles.snippet: The third generation of the gas-electric car was an instant hit in Japan, where plants are working 24 hours a day.
articles.abstract: The third generation of the gas-electric car was an instant hit in Japan, where plants are working 24 hours a day.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOYOTA CITY, Japan  Throughout Toyota’s global operations, managers are scrambling to cut costs in the wake of record losses.

articles.headline: Protests Flare in Tehran as Opposition Disputes Vote
articles.snippet: The streets of Iran’s capital erupted in the most intense protests in a decade as riot police officers clashed with demonstrators who accused Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of stealing the election.
articles.abstract: The streets of Iran’s capital erupted in the most intense protests in a decade as riot police officers clashed with demonstrators who accused Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of stealing the election.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN  The streets of Iran’s capital erupted in the most intense protests in a decade on Saturday, with riot police officers using batons and tear gas against opposition demonstrators who claimed that President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad had stolen the presidential election.
articles.byline: By Robert F. Worth and Nazila Fathi

articles.headline: Reverberations as Door Slams on Hope of Change
articles.snippet: Iran’s election ended with smoldering anger, crushed hopes and punctured illusions on the ground in Tehran and in the policy centers of Western capitals.
articles.abstract: Iran’s election ended with smoldering anger, crushed hopes and punctured illusions on the ground in Tehran and in the policy centers of Western capitals.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN  It is impossible to know for sure how much the ostensible re-election of Mahmoud Ahmadinejad represents the preference of an essentially conservative Iranian public and how much, as opposition voters passionately believe, it is the imposed verdict of a fundamentally authoritarian regime.

articles.headline: Checkmate at the Yellowstone Club
articles.snippet: Edra Blixseth is at the center of a huge financial mess, court papers show, and she is losing her once-prized asset, the Yellowstone Club.
articles.abstract: Edra Blixseth is at the center of a huge financial mess, court papers show, and she is losing her once-prized asset, the Yellowstone Club.
articles.lead_paragraph: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif.

articles.headline: Debts Coming Due at Just the Wrong Time
articles.snippet: Banks face waves of short-term debt that will be hard, or impossible, to refinance.
articles.abstract: Banks face waves of short-term debt that will be hard, or impossible, to refinance.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEN banks slipped out from under the TARP last week, striking deals with the Treasury Department to repay taxpayer money they received last fall. Many bailout-weary investors and taxpayers welcomed this sign that government intervention in the financial sector may finally be receding.

articles.headline: As U.S. Overhauls the Banking System, 2 Top Regulators Feud
articles.snippet: The personal feud between two bank regulators is shaping the president’s attempt to revamp financial regulation.
articles.abstract: The personal feud between two bank regulators is shaping the president’s attempt to revamp financial regulation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Two of the nation’s most powerful bank regulators were once again at each other’s throats.
articles.byline: By Stephen Labaton and Edmund L. Andrews

articles.headline: Unrest Deepens as Critics Are Detained
articles.snippet: Candidates and clerics requested an annulment of the election, but Mr. Ahmadinejad hinted that his challenger risks punishment for questioning the result.
articles.abstract: Candidates and clerics requested an annulment of the election, but Mr. Ahmadinejad hinted that his challenger risks punishment for questioning the result.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN  Violence and acrimony over Iran’s disputed election intensified on Sunday, with word spreading that more than 100 prominent opposition members had been detained, riots erupting in Tehran and other cities, and the triumphant incumbent hinting that his top challenger risks punishment for questioning the result.
articles.byline: By Robert F. Worth and Nazila Fathi

articles.headline: Netanyahu Backs Palestinian State, With Caveats
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu endorsed the idea of a Palestinian state for the first time, but Palestinians immediately rejected his conditions.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu endorsed the idea of a Palestinian state for the first time, but Palestinians immediately rejected his conditions.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM  The prime minister of Israel, Benjamin Netanyahu, on Sunday endorsed for the first time the principle of a Palestinian state alongside Israel, but on condition that the state was demilitarized and that the Palestinians recognized Israel as the state of the Jewish people.

articles.headline: If The Globe Were Sold, What Price?
articles.snippet: People with track records in valuing media properties were asked to assess The Boston Globe. Their answers were surprising.
articles.abstract: People with track records in valuing media properties were asked to assess The Boston Globe. Their answers were surprising.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not that long ago, owning a metropolitan newspaper guaranteed a seat at the civic table, immediate respectability and, given that many papers were near-monopolies, a press practically capable of printing money.

articles.headline: Providing Cellphones for the Poor
articles.snippet: A federal program providing subsidized phone service now offers cellphones, showing how much society values them.
articles.abstract: A federal program providing subsidized phone service now offers cellphones, showing how much society values them.
articles.lead_paragraph: John Cobb, 59, a former commercial fisherman who is disabled with cirrhosis of the liver and emphysema, lives in a studio apartment in Greensboro, N.C., on a fixed monthly income of $674. He has been hoping to receive more government assistance, and in February, he did.

articles.headline: Insurance Giant A.I.G. Takes Ex-Chief to Court
articles.snippet: The company contends Maurice R. Greenberg plundered a trust that it says was set up to pay top performers.
articles.abstract: The company contends Maurice R. Greenberg plundered a trust that it says was set up to pay top performers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The latest act in the drama of the American International Group opens Monday when the ailing insurance giant takes its former chief executive to court, accusing him of plundering a trust that it says was set up to pay top performers.

articles.headline: On a Furlough, but Never Leaving the Cubicle
articles.snippet: Plans to turn unpaid days into modest holidays have given way to a different reality as some employees work quietly — and sometimes openly — through furloughs.
articles.abstract: Plans to turn unpaid days into modest holidays have given way to a different reality as some employees work quietly — and sometimes openly — through furloughs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wendy Roberson, a state employee in California, founded the Fun Furlough Fridays Club partly as a joke, but also because she honestly believed that she would be having long-weekend-type fun on her forced time off.
articles.byline: By Susan Saulny and Robbie Brown

articles.headline: Even Forbes Is Pinching Pennies
articles.snippet: The recession is testing Forbes magazine and the family behind it, long symbols of the fruits of capitalism.
articles.abstract: The recession is testing Forbes magazine and the family behind it, long symbols of the fruits of capitalism.
articles.lead_paragraph: With its yearly list of the most fabulously wealthy and legion of articles lionizing business leaders, Forbes magazine has long been a synonym for riches, success and a belief that business, left to its own devices, will create a better world.

articles.headline: A World of Risk for a New Brand of Journalist
articles.snippet: Freelancers and others on unconventional assignments for start-up news organizations may find fewer resources to help them when they are in danger.
articles.abstract: Freelancers and others on unconventional assignments for start-up news organizations may find fewer resources to help them when they are in danger.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the journalists Laura Ling and Euna Lee complete their third month of detainment in North Korea, it remains rather astonishing that they were there in the first place to report for a fledgling cable channel. But their path there may explain in part why they remain in custody.

articles.headline: Leader Emerges With Stronger Hand
articles.snippet: President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad’s victory demonstrated that he is the shrewd front man for an elite more unified than at any time since 1979.
articles.abstract: President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad’s victory demonstrated that he is the shrewd front man for an elite more unified than at any time since 1979.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN  The jokes among Mahmoud Ahmadinejad’s detractors are legion. In one, he looks in the mirror and says, “Male lice to the right, female lice to the left.” In the West, one American tabloid rarely misses a chance to refer to him as “Evil Madman” and in the days before his re-election here he was taunted as a “monkey” and as a “midget.”
articles.byline: By Bill Keller and Michael Slackman

articles.headline: Defiance Grows as Iran’s Leader Sets Vote Review
articles.snippet: Hundreds of thousands of people marched in Tehran to protest Iran’s disputed presidential election, in what appeared to be the largest anti-government demonstration in Iran since the 1979 revolution.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of thousands of people marched in Tehran to protest Iran’s disputed presidential election, in what appeared to be the largest anti-government demonstration in Iran since the 1979 revolution.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN  Hundreds of thousands of people marched in silence through central Tehran on Monday to protest Iran’s disputed presidential election in an extraordinary show of defiance from a broad cross section of society, even as the nation’s supreme leader called for a formal review of results he had endorsed two days earlier.
articles.byline: By Robert F. Worth and Nazila Fathi

articles.headline: Shares in Retreat on Fear of Slow, Late Recovery
articles.snippet: Stock markets slid as commodity prices fell, but government bonds regained ground and the dollar strengthened.
articles.abstract: Stock markets slid as commodity prices fell, but government bonds regained ground and the dollar strengthened.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hopes for an economic rebound lifted Wall Street off the mat this spring. But on Monday, investors took cover in a broad sell-off as they faced the prospect that any recovery could be slow and a long way off.
